q: Which sentence is in the second conditional?
options: If I were rich, I would travel the world.
If I was rich, I travel the world.

If I will be rich, I would travel the world.

options: He has worked at the moment.

options: She is singing a song right now.

q: Which option correctly changes "I am going to the party" into reported speech?
options: He said that he went to the party.
He said that he goes to the party.
He said that he was going to the party.

q: What is the reported form of "I will visit my grandparents next week"?
options: He said that he will visit his grandparents next week.
He said that he would visit his grandparents the following week.
He said that he would visit his grandparents next week.

He said that he had finished his homework.

q: When do we use a relative clause?
options: To provide additional information about a noun

q: What is the purpose of a relative pronoun?
options: To connect a dependent clause to its antecedent
To link a verb to a subject

q: What is the reporting counterpart of "what time is it"?
options: She asked what time it was?
she asked what time is it
she asked what time it is

q: What is the purpose of reported speech?
options: To retell what someone else said
To tell a story about what someone said

q: Which of the following is the correct WH-question for asking about frequency?

options: Have you never been to Paris?

options: you know what time it is?

q: Which sentence is in the past perfect tense?
options: She had left before I arrived.
She has left before I arrived.
She was leaving before I arrived.

q: Which sentence uses 'going to' for a future plan?
options: I will go to the cinema yesterday.
I am going to visit my aunt tomorrow.
I go to visit my aunt tomorrow.

Look, it's raining. I'll take an umbrella.

q: Which sentence is a zero conditional?
options: If it rains, we will stay inside.
If you heat ice, it melts.

q: Which sentence is a first conditional?
options: If it rains, we stayed inside.
If it rains, we will stay inside.
If it rained, we would stay inside.
If it had rained, we would have stayed inside.

q: Which sentence is a third conditional?
options: If I knew, I would tell you.
If I know, I will tell you.
If I had known, I would have told you.
If I was knowing, I would tell you.
